Traditional English Cider apple. For cider - Full body. Rich. Slight residual sweetness is noticeable with the low acidity. Pleasant tannins - lightly drying and slight bitterness. Notes of oak, spiced rum, molasses, anise.
Overall Impression - Wow! Definitely a stand out cider apple. Wish more ciders tasted like that. Total tannins=0.20%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/yarlington-mill

From the banks of the Wolf River in Wisconsin. For cider - Low to medium body. Classic tart apple flavor. Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - Good base apple with a straight-forward tart apple flavor. Would be enjoyable on a hot day when floating down the Wolf River. Total tannins=0.11%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/new-page

Intense, well known English cider apple very high in tannins. For cider -Unfortunately we did not have enough juice from Tremlett's Bitter to create a single varietal cider for further testing. Total tannins=1.20%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/tremletts-bitter

For cider - Light to medium body. Low to medium acidity. Mild apple flavor. Little to no noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression - Unremarkable, but not bad. Total tannins=0.10%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/stump

For cider - Medium body. Medium to high acidity. Mild bitterness and astringency fills out the cider. Overall Impression - Nice, balanced. Good all around. Total tannins=0.20%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/swiss-limbertwig-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider -Medium body and acidity. The residual sweetness is more noticeable than it was for most of the ciders we tested (we won't speculate as to the reason since there are a number of possible explanations). Not much noticeable tannin except for a hint of astringency on the finish. Overall Impression - Very drinkable. Very good. Well balanced on its own and great for a base. Total tannins=0.15%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/smokehouse-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - Medium body. Medium to high acidity. Not much noticeable tannin presence except that the flavor seems lightly nutty and spiced.
Overall Impression - A good cider but not exceptional. Interesting in subtle ways. Could benefit from higher gravity or more tannins. Total tannins=0.15%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/slippery-cider-apple-cider-evaluation

Also known as Jeidy Russet. For cider - Full body. High acidity. Rich, puckery fruit flavors. Long, mouth-watering finish. Mild bitterness and astringency rounds out the cider.
Overall Impression - Very good cider. From it's cold Wisconsin home, this apple produces a surprising, tart fruit punch that brings memories of warmer weather and can carry one away to a bright, tropical place even on a wintry night. Total tannins=0.25%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/wisconsin-russet-apple-cider-evaluation

Variable sized apple also known as Fameuse. Bi-color green and red. Originated from plantings by French settlers in Quebec. For cider - Soft mouthfeel and a bit thin. Mildly tart with some lingering acidity. Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - A light, refreshing cider. A good cider base with balanced acidity that would blend well with a bittersweet.Total tannins=0.06%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/snow-apple-cider-evaluation

Crunchy medium size apple. For cider - Medium body. High acidity. Long, tart finish. Little to no noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression - Perhaps too one dimensional to stand on its own but could be used to add acidity to a blend. Total tannins=0.06%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/russet-cow

Large, very similar to a regular Cortland, just a bit redder. For cider - Low to medium body. Light at first with a tart, lingering finish. Medium acidity overall. Little to no noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression - Very drinkable cider. Fine for a base apple. Might be nice to have a higher gravity apple to fill it out, but it's nonetheless enjoyable as a light, refreshing cider. Total tannins=0.06%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/red-cortland-apple-cider-evaluation

Similar to Golden Delicious. For cider - Medium body. Alcohol bite fills it out. Nice acidity level - not too high, not too low. Little to no noticeable tannins. Pleasant apple/grape flavor.
Overall Impression - A very good cider on its own. It's attractive, and everything is in nice balance (except that it lacks tannins). Total tannins=0.08%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/razor-russet-apple-cider-evaluation

Rich dark plum colored apple from Washington state For cider - Medium body. Very tart, like cranberry juice. Long finish. Little to no noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression - Great apple for bumping up the acidity of a blend. Full tart flavor. Total tannins=0.09%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/raven

Origin unknown, pleasant and juicy. For cider - Medium body. Medium to high acidity. Lightly drying and mildly bitter. Long, dry finish with lingering acidity and bitterness.
Overall Impression - Very good cider on its own. Nice balance of acidity and tannins. Total tannins=0.15%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/plumb-cider

Old English heiloom. For cider - Medium body. Impressively tart. Like pineapple juice without any sugar. Brisk, full flavor. Long, tart finish. Little noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression - A distinctive cider. Too acidic on its own for some palettes. Would liven up a blend with some tropical tang. Total tannins=0.10%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/pitmaston-pineapple-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - Moderate, soft mouthfeel that gives way to full and long lasting acidity. Little noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression – Great for adding aromatics and acidity to a blend, a little too acidic on its own. Total tannins=0.10%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/shiawassee

Seeling apple from Iola Wisconson. For cider - Medium body leaning towards light. Nice acidity - not too strong, not too weak. Easy to drink, green apple flavor with a note of pine. Little to no noticeable tannins.
Overall Impression - Exceptionally drinkable cider. Light and refreshing. Total tannins=0.09%.
https://brixcider.com/northwest-greening-apple-cider-evaluation

Heirloom apple from the 1800s. For cider - Moderate mouthfeel. Little acidity. Noticeable tannins, mildly bitter and astringent. Slightly woody, leathery flavor.
Overall Impression – A unique cider both in terms of the story of the apple and its uncommon flavor. Could be bumped up with a higher gravity, higher acidity apple, but interesting on its own.Total tannins=0.16%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/minkler-apple-cider-evaluation

Popular eating apple. For cider - Medium body. Fresh, tart apple flavor. Moderate to strong acidity. Overall Impression – This common eating apple makes a pleasant cider with the familiar tart apple flavor of a Mac. Great base apple. Could make for a world class cider if blended with a bittersweet. Total tannins=0.11%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/macintosh-apple-cider-evaluation

Seeling apple from Iola Wisconson. For cider - Medium body. High acidity dominates the flavor, like “biting into a lemon” though there is nothing particularly citric about it. Long, tart, dry finish. No noticeable bitterness but some astringency.
Overall Impression – A good cider apple overall. Probably too tart on its own for most palettes, but the acidity and moderate astringency would lend well to a blend. Total tannins=0.19%.
For more info see - https://brixcider.com/perry-russet

French Cider Apple. For cider - Full mouthfeel. Sherry-like. Noticeable sweetness with the low acidity. Soft tannins. Woody. Baked apple, raisin. Alcohol finish. Overall Impression - Excellent cider. Rich, complex. Highly recommended. Total tannins=0.31%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/marin-oufroy-apple-cider-evaluation

Crisp with a pleasant apple flavor but not very juicy. For cider - Fresh apple flavor. Refreshing and balanced. Medium body, medium acidity, little to no tannin.
Overall Impression – Enjoyable cider. Classic apple flavor. Total tannins=0.07%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/london-pippen-apple-cider-evaluation

Mild flavor. For cider - Low acidity. Light mouthfeel. Mild apple skin flavor. Little to no noticeable tannins. Mild cider overall. Nothing remarkable but nothing bad. Easy to drink. Could mellow an overly sharp cider. Total tannins=0.07%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/lady-sweet

Popular eating variety. For cider - Medium to light body. Moderate acidity. Little to no noticeable tannins. Nothing exciting but not bad. Would make a good, neutral base for blending with other apples. Mild apple flavor. Total tannins=0.07%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/honeycrisp-apple-cider-evaluation

From Northern Germany. For cider - Medium body. Medium to high acidity. Subtle but noticeable bitterness. Little astringency. Long, tart finish. Makes a pretty good cider, would add some acidity, unique aroma, and subtle bitterness to a blend.Total tannins=0.13%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/horneburger-pancake

For cider -Mellow, straight-forward apple flavor. Unassuming on first sip but a long, lingering finish. Moderate acidity. Little to no noticeable tannins. Light, subtle, and drinkable. Unadorned apple flavor and aroma. Would make a fine backdrop for blending with almost any apple. Total tannins=0.08%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/hauer-pippin-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - medium to light in body, medium acidity, a mild tart apple. Slightly more astringent than low tannin would expect. Total tannins=0.08%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/carroll

Slightly tart apple from Minnesota. For cider - Light to medium body. Medium to slightly high acidity. A hint of something funky - perhaps something wasn't perfectly clean and happy during the fermentation (we don't claim to be perfect). Little to no noticeable tannins. Probably could have been better (blame the cider maker). Even so, it was a little thin. Could be used to add some acidity to a blend. Total tannins=0.10%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/haralson-apple-cider-evaluation

Heirloom apple. For cider - Green apple skin. Even tart flavor from start to finish. Mild bitterness and astringency. Distinctly "green apple" cider. Refreshing, balanced. Very good on its own. Total tannins=0.12%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/grimes-golden-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - Initial burst of flavor and gushing, juicy mouthfeel that fades to a lingering astringency. Moderate acidity and notable "bite" of alcohol. The astringent finish suggests more tannins than testing revealed. Good, full flavored cider with nice balance of acids. It stands up fairly well on its own or could be used to add some oomph to a weaker cider. Total tannins=0.12%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/gloster-apple-cider-evaluation

An apple grafted from a tree at the Garfield Farm Museum in LaFox, Illinois. Excellent cider. Nicely balanced. Intriguing aroma and full flavor. Intriguing story to the apple as well.Total tannins=0.16%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/garfield

Popular Eating Apple. For cider - Straight forward cider flavor. Medium body. Medium to low acidity. Little to no tannins. Simple. Clean, very easy to drink. Nothing exciting but not bad. Total tannins=0.05%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/gala-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - Medium body, noticeable alcohol. Moderate to high acidity, like tart cherry juice. Long finish. Little noticeable tannins. Total tannins=0.12%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/egremont-russet-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider -Medium body. Dominated by tart, lingering green apple acidity, somewhat biting but not overly harsh. Little noticeable tannins. Total tannins=0.07%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/coopers-market-apple-cider-evaluation

Known as Alkmene in Germany where it was initially grown. For cider - Medium to light body. Medium to high acidity. Long tart finish. Slightly drying but otherwise no noticeable tannins.. Total tannins=0.11%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/earlywindsor

Popular eating apple bred in NY in the late 1800s. For cider -Low to medium body. Moderate acidity - starts mild then builds and fades slowly. Little to no noticeable tannins. Mild sour apple flavor. Not an exciting cider, but may work well in a blend. Total tannins=0.06%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/cortland-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - Medium to light body. Moderate to slightly high acidity with a long finish. Little in the way of tannins. Good cider base, straightforward. Total tannins=0.11%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/christmas-pearmain-apple-cider-evaluation

Cider making variety. Medium to medium large. Full bodied, balanced, sharp cider apple with a pleasant bite. Notable but mild tannins, some woody notes. Wine like. Total tannins=0.14%
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/black-gilliflower-apple-cider-evaluation

For cider - low in aroma, tart, highly acidic with some astringency. Somewhat tart on its own but may be a good apple for a blend. Total tannins = 0.12%.
For more info see: https://brixcider.com/blenheim-orange
Distinctive floral aromas. Easily crystalizes. Light to medium amber in color.
The most common variety sold in supermarkets with a huge annual production. Delicate and relatively neutral in flavor. Some variation due to the large production area.
Made from Basswood blossoms in North America. One of the few light colored honeys that has a strong biting flavor. Woody scents and a strong biting flavor.
Alfalfa is a light, delicate honey made from bees feeding on alfalfa. In meads is delicate and fairly clean in flavor.
Acacia honey is made from the nectar of black locust plants. Very sweet with a mild delicate floral taste. High fructose content, often used therapeutically.
Sage honey is made primarily in California. It is heavy bodied but has a mild flavor. It is often blended with other honeys as it does not easily granulate.
Sourwood honey is sweet, light colored and dlicate. It has a caramel or buttery flavor to it and a pleasant buttery aftertaste.
Produced primarily in Italy from the blossoms of chesnut trees. Has a unique aroma and slightly bitter flavor. Amber in color, and only mildly sweet.
Fireweed comes from a perennial herb grown in the Pacific North West US. Sweet, complex, buttery taste. Buttery finish.
Medium light in color and very sweet. Some fruity character comes thorugh from the blackberries.

The champagne of honey. Highly prized by many mead makers. Tupelo honey is light amber with a slightly greenish color and a pear-like hoppy aroma. Delicate, mild, buttery, floral. Works well with many fruits.
Deep flavor profile from bees foraging on blueberry bushes. Mid color range with a slightly fruity character.

Made once a year from the nectar of Pumpkin Blossoms in early fall. Dark, amber colored with a light floral fragrance. Works well when contrasted with spicy foods and spices. It does not taste like pumpkin pie, however.
Raspberry honey from the white blossoms of the raspberry bush. Amber in color, mellow finish and hints of raspberry. Slightly fruity and pairs well with vanilla.
Light, delicate and hints of mesquite flavor, but not smoky. Makes a nice single variety mead if you enjoy the flavor of the honey.
Orange blossom honey is a favorite of fruit mead makers. A delicate fragrance, sweet and clean fermenting. Fragrant, light, heady, slight hints of orange blossom.
Slightly bitter with an aftertaste of burnt caramel. Dark amber in color.
A rich distinctive honey made from bees foraging Eucalyptus trees in Australia. A full body honey with hints of Eucalyptus.

Wildflower bees capture nectars from a wide variety of trees, shrubs, and flowers. Some variability due to wide range of production. Deep, rich, and not as sweet as clover honey. Some examples really capture wild character of flora used.
Quite a bit of variability in production - so sample before using.
Mild and fruity in flavor with a tart aftertaste. Medium amber color.
A flavorful, earthy honey made by bees foraging on avacado trees. Dark amber color. Hints of molasses and sorghum, a rich, full bodied flavorful honey.

Probably the strongest and darkets of varietal honey. Dark in color. Strong molasses finish and capable of making "single malt" meads. Can be musty and earthy in aroma. Some eastern varieties can take on a "barnyard" character though western US versions are less so.
The strong flavor can overwhelm/conflict with many fruits and spices, so select complementatry flavor combos.

Generic honey - usually Clover honey is sold in US supermarkets. Will generally lighten body and flavor when used in beer as it is highly fermentable. Modern methods add honey directly to the primary to avoid boiling away aroma and flavor. Some varieties have additional flavors (see the Honey Varietals add-on).

Knudsen's 'Organic Just Prune' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Organic Just Tart Cherry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Organic Just Pomegranate' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Organic Just Concord Grape' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Just Pomegranate' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Just Tart Cherry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Organic Just Cranberry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Just Black Cherry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.
Note - their tart cherry has more tannins and will produce more flavor post-fermentation.

Knudsen's 'Just Blueberry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Just Cranberry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

Knudsen's 'Just Black Currant' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer. Sold in 1 quart jars. Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.
Light to medium amber in color and a hint of apple in the aroma.
Pale wheat malt, used as a base malt in many wheat styles. Wheat beers, Koelsch, Alts.
Darker wheat malt, used as a base malt in many wheat styles. Wheat beers, Koelsch, Alts.
Vienna base malt - used in many continental beer styles. Full bodied, golden color.
Smoked flavor and aroma base malt. Used in smoked ales, lagers and wheat beers, primarily German styles.
A unique coloring agent in liquid form. Schwartz beer, colour adjustment.Roast malt beer extract.
Rye malt for rye style beers. Up to 50% may be used in some rye styles. Adds distinctive rye flavor and aroma.
Pilsner base malt for all pilsners, lagers. Highly modified malt.
Pale base malt for all ales and lagers. Good general purpose malt.
Darker Munich Malt. Used as a base malt in many German beer styles. Fest beers, bocks and ales. Enhances malt flavour and aroma
Light Munich malt. May be used as a base for many German beer styles. Fest beers, bocks, ales. Enhances malty flavour and aroma
Red colored malt that improved head retention and stability. Used in red lagers, ales, dark beers. Intense red colour and malty aroma.
Chocholate malt made with a wheat base. Adds aroma and color. Alts and dark wheat beers.
Roasted malt made with a rye base. Adds aroma, flavor and color. Used in rye styles.
Used in wheat beers and ales. A wheat version of crystal malt. Promotes fuller flavor, wheat malt aroma and enhanced color.
Medium crystal malt, adds a body and reddish color. Red ales and lagers, Scottish ales. Full body and aroma, deep red colour
German crystal malt. Adds maltiness, body, aroma and color.
German crystal malt. Adds maltiness, aroma, color.
German crystal malt. Adds maltiness, flavor, color and aroma.
Caramel malt made with a rye base. Adds aroma, flavor and color. Used in rye styles.
Light colored caramel malt. Adds body, color and aroma. Use up to 30% in low alcohol beers
Carafoam (also called Carapils) adds body and head retention without substantially altering flavor. Up to 10% for light beers, 40% for mashed beers
De-husked chocolate malt for a smoother flavour. Dark version. Adds color and aroma. Dark beers, Alts, Bockbiers
De-husked chocolate malt for a smoother flavor. Adds body, color, aroma. Dark beers, Alts, Bockbiers
Chocolate malt. Dark beers, Alts, Bockbiers. Adds color and aroma. De-husked, smoother tasting
Chocolate malt. Dark beers, Alts, Bockbiers. Adds color and aroma.
Chocolate malt. Dark beers, Alts, Bockbiers. Adds color and aroma.
Chocolate malt. Dark beers, Alts, Bockbiers. Adds color and aroma.
Very dark caramel malt with aromatic properties. Adds deep red color and aroma. Amber ales, dark lagers, bocks. Substitute for "Belgian Special B" or 120L caramel malts.
Medium colored caramel malt. Bocks, dark ales, red and amber lagers and ales. Improves flavour stability and enhances colour
Used in Germany to lower PH levels without resorting to chemicals. Lowers mash pH levels, lightens color, improves flavor stability.

Usage: Schwarzbier, dark beers, Stout, Porter, Ale, Bockbier, Altbier, dark wheat beers, all beer types for colouring.
Description: BlackSwaen©Chocolate W roasted wheat malt is for top fermented beers, used in amounts of 1% for Altbier or dark wheat beers. To enhance colour and mild toast hints. For real specialties, in a special way.
Results: Improved colour as well as intensified aroma of dark, top fermented beers. Slight roast aroma.
Rate: Up to 5%.

Wheat malt can be added at 5% to most light beers to increase foam stability without affecting haze or flavour. Used up to 70% as a base malt for wheat beer, it imparts a bready flavour and characteristic citrus notes.

Simpson's Vienna malt enhances the light colour, flavour and aroma of all light beers. Light, bready, malty notes bring body to Light Ales, Best Bitters and Czech Lagers. Use as a base malt for highly hopped IPA and American Ales to provide great balance and depth.

Roasted Barley is a typical ingredient of dry Irish Stouts. Although the colour specification is very similar to Black Malt, Roasted Barley has an intense coffee/roast flavour, bestowing a deep dark colour with flavours to match.
Red Rye Crystal imparts a beautiful ruby red hue to beers whilst offering a well-rounded, sweet, malty flavour. Great Autumnal flavour for seasonal beers.

Malted Rye contributes a spicy rye note to beers. It adds a unique flavour to beer giving fullness and mouthfeel. Great used in conjunction with Red Rye Crystal. Rice husks are recommended if using at greater than 20% to aid filtration. As well as using in traditional Rye Beers, Malted Rye is excellent in hoppy Beer styles, complimenting citrus hops with its spice.Styles: Rye IPA and Speciality Beers.

For the principal ingredient in keg, bottle or cask ales, Simpsons use top quality UK two-row barley to produce a plump, well-modified malt with good extract and enzymic activity. The versatility of this base malt lends itself to balance hoppy beers or provide a robust malty note to a Traditional Bitter or Belgian-style beer.

Grain.F_G_NAME: Pale Ale, Low Colour Maris Otter (Simpsons)
Grain.F_G_NOTES: If you require a well modified, high performing malt, but with a low colour, look no further than Low Colour Maris Otter. This heritage barley variety is used to produce an exceptional quality base malts, with high extract and enzymic activity and low nitrogen content. It is kilned at a low temperature, making it perfect for Cask IPAs and Light Coloured Ales.

When you need a high performing well balanced malt to complement your big hops, you won't lose out on body. This gives the biggest base of any malt without adding colour, resulting in exceptional beers.

Maris Otter's superior Brewhouse performance is fantastic. The Rolls Royce of malts for the traditional brewer, this legendary heritage barley variety is the Traditional English Bitter base malt. It produces a rich malty flavour with exceptional Brewhouse performance and beer clarity, due to its low nitrogen content and high extract.

Extra Pale Ale Malt is an excellent base malt for Brewers who require a low colour, well modified malt. The plump grains of UK two-row barley ensure uniformity and consistency, as well as good extract and enzymic activity. If you're limited on base malt storage, it doubles as a great light coloured base for both Lagers and Ales.

Simpsons Malted Oats have large, thick husks which helps with run off. Once you crack it open, the creaminess of the oats releases a silky smoothness which imparts a sumptuous velvety texture to your beer. This fullness allows it to take as many hops as you can throw at it for a juice bomb, providing balance. In more traditional usage, Malted Oats provide the back bone of creaminess in Oatmeal Stouts and Porters, smoothing the astringency that may result from the heavy use of roasted grains and adding a complexity of flavour. Malted Oats is a hugely versatile product that can be added to any beer style to impart a creamy, velvety smooth mouthfeel.

This huskless oat crystal malt is quite simply delicious. An exotic ingredient for the adventurous brewer, it brings a subtle nutty flavour. Its creaminess brings mouthfeel and balance to strong, hop forward beers. One taste and we're sure you'll be inspired to start creating a new recipe.

Simpson's Munich malt brings rich malty flavours and golden hues to light beers. If you are struggling to bring up the mouthfeel in really hoppy keg beers, try adding a generous proportion of Munich to your grist. An excellent base malt for Strong Bitter, Dark Amber Ales, Brown Ales and Milds. It brings intense colour and malty notes without compromising enzymic action. Despite its continental name, this malt provides a fantastic malty base for British Ales and Bitters.

Finest Lager Malt is a superb low colour lager malt. Well modified, high extract UK spring two row barley gives high enzymic activity, low colour, low nitrogen and exceptional Brewhouse performance. It can be used to make any style of lager with its clean, light malty taste.
Simpson's Imperial Malt imparts a full-bodied flavour and biscuit aroma. The warm brown notes it adds to the wort intensify the dept of colour, without compromising enzymic activity.

A handy little tool to keep up your sleeve, Dextrin Malt can be used sparingly to add body, mouthfeel and foam stability to any beer. Particularly useful in very light, hop forward IPAs to balance bitterness. It is great in lower attenuated sweet beers such as Mild and sweet Stout.

The secret is in the name - Target 50! Each batch targets 50 Lovibond colour (130EBC). The specification on Crystal T50 was created with one of their most acclaimed clients in mind. With an exceptionally tight consistency - it's fantastic crystal that crunches in the mouth offering. Crystal T50 provides amazing colour and delicate malty flavours to beer.

Caramel and toffee notes come to the forefront in Simpsons' Crystal Medium. Their expert roasters use their skills to bring you a crystal that adds stunning deep golden and red hues to your beer, whilst imparting deeper caramel notes.

Simpson's Crystal Light brings mild caramel and toffee flavours to beers whilst contributing a beautiful golden hue. Its clean, mild sweetness brings depth of flavour to beers where extra body is required, without adding overtly toasted or roasted characters.

The uniformity and excellent malting characteristics that have ensured Maris Otter has been the favoured barley variety of the British Brewer, also lends itself to ensure exceptionally good crystal malt. Simpsons have hand crafted this heritage barley variety to produce an outstanding medium crystal bringing flavour and depth of colour to Ales and Bitters.

The beautiful rich brown of the grain gives an insight to the exquisite dried fruit and burnt sugar flavours that are imparted by this expertly crafted dark crystal. Used in small amounts, this malt will help balance flavour and colour in dark beers whilst enhancing head retention.

With Simpsons' Crystal Dark, we get into the delicious realms of complex toffee and burnt sugar but without the astringency of roasted malt. Their unique roasting process for crystals allows them to produce exceptional uniformity in each batch, to ensure each grain of malt is perfectly crystallized.

Due to its unique production process, Simpsons' DRC® can be used to substitute darker roasted malts in dark beers where the astringency and bitterness inherent to roast malts is not desired. This means that it can be used at a higher rate in the grist to add complex caramel and dried fruit notes with a beautiful red-brown hue.
Simpsons' Chocolate Malt gives beer a stunning dark brown colour. Chocolate overtones and hints of coffee bring richness and complexity at higher usages in Stouts and Porters.

Simpson's Premium English Caramalt is their top of the range Cara. Used in light coloured beers, it will impart a deliciously sweet malty flavour without the burnt character that higher colour crystals bring. Excellent for colour adjustment on delicately flavoured lagers and ales it gives a slight colour increase. Also works well in highly hopped beer to balance out bitterness and citrus aromas.

Simpson's Caramalt is a chewy, sweet taste of Heaven. It contributes golden hued colour enhacement and flavour enrichment from its mild toffee notes in Lagers and Extra Pale Ales. Due to its low colour, it is incredibly versatile and can be used to enhance almost any Beer style that needs a little sweetnes.

Simpsons' Brown Malt imparts a rich coffee aroma ideal for Stouts and Porters. It delivers a smooth mouthfeel as well as increasing foam stability. The hue is a deep mahogany that brings warmth and depth to dark beers. Often a forgotten malt.

Simpsons' Black Malt is excellent for darkening beer colour without imparting too much astringency or roast characteristics. The flavour is surprisingly neutral with a clean dryness making it an incredibly versatile product.

The secret weapon in the British Ale Brewer's arsenal, Simpsons' aromatic malt has a slightly higher acidity to balance pH. Its complex sweetness with sour after-notes gives a magnificent mouthfeel. This, combined with intense malty notes and raisin, makes aromatic malt a versatile product that can be used from as little as 5% to give warm honey aromas and up to 50% as a base malt for dark beers to give raisin and plum notes. Brings a beautiful brown depth of colour.

Perhaps the most versatile of all Simpsons' roasted products, Simpsons' Amber Malt can be used in a wide variety of beers to add biscuity toasty notes and a beautiful brown hue. Its delicate roast flavour makes it suitable for adding toasty notes to all Dark Beers, as well as lighter Ales and Lagers. Amber Malt brings a clean, crisp dryness to balance delicate floral hops and increases foam stability.

Curing temperature of 95 to 105°C. Provides the basis for the dark beer character is used up to 100% of the grist. Swaen©Munich light imparts the basis of the dark beer character. Results: Enhanced dark beer body, head and aroma.

Common household baking sugar. Lightens flavor and body of beer. Can contribute a cider-like flavor to the beer if not cold-fermented or used in large quantities.

Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. It has the unmistakable flavors of fresh ground coffee, dark stone fruit, and hint of dark toasted bread with some notes of anise and dark chocolate. D-180 is the basis for many dark Belgian Ales.

Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. The most versatile of our Belgian style Candi Syrups and is made with pure Beet sugar. This syrup creates an unmistakable and subtle mild palate of dark chocolate, dark stone fruit, slight hint of coffee, toffee, and medium-toasted bread notes. This syrup will insure the caramel aroma and rich flavors of award winning Belgian style ales.

Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. A rich translucent amber syrup. The unmistakable toffee, vanilla, caramel, and lightly toasted flavors. Exceedingly good in Brown Ales or medium Golden Ale's that require an aromatic nose and subtle flavor.
Dark Brown Soft Candi Sugar. The darkest and most flavorful cassonade on the market. It contributes notable dark fruit and subtle caramel flavors at the same time. Ideal for all darker ales.
Light Brown Soft Candi Sugar. A slightly lighter premium Soft Candi Sugar with delicate and smooth toasted caramel overtones. Ideal for Dubbels and Belgian Pale's.

Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. A decadent Golden Belgian style Candi Syrup that contributes rich caramel flavors followed by a subtle fruit back-palate. Good in Belgian Golden Ale's, Tripels, Bier de Garde, Saison, Belgian Blonde, and all lighter Belgian Ale's.

Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. A good balance of highly fermentable sugars with a faint "citrusy" flavor and/or mild honey palate. A unique blonde Belgian style Candi Syrup. Good for Saisons, Triples, and Golden Ale's. It is readily fermentable and creates a refreshing subtle flavor.
White Soft Candi Sugar. A neutral premium Soft Sugar ideal for Tripels and as an adjunct to lighten the body of any ale. Adds a light caramel to light or dark Belgian style ales.
Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer. Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.

Basismout voor alle tarwebieren, maar wordt ook in kleinere hoeveelheden gestort voor het verkrijgen van een "brood"-toets. Zorgt voor een kruidige smaak in het bier en bevordert de schuimvorming. Wordt tot 50% gestort.

Used to add mouthfeel to a beer. It is marked as non-fermentable as it is usually 97% unfermentable sugars.
White wheat gives a malty flavor not available from raw wheat. Used in Weiss, Wit and White beers

Unmodified wheat that has been "popped" to open the kernels Used primarily in place of raw wheat when making Belgian White and Wit Faster conversion and higher yield than raw wheat Protein rest recommended when mashing

Also called Chocolate Wheat Malt. Kilned raw wheat - adds a deep, dark brown color to dunkelweizens and other dark beer styles. Roasted, woody, charcoal or burnt toast flavor depending on degree of roasting.

Flaked wheat adds to increased body and foam retention Used in place of raw or torrified wheat for faster conversion and better yield. May be used in small amounts to improve head retention and body Examples: Belgian White beer, Wit
Malted wheat base for use in all wheat styles
Dark malted wheat base for use in dark wheat styles such as Dunkleweizen.
Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers
Generally a neutral flavor, used to reduce maltiness of beer Produces beer with a milder, less malty flavor Uses: Primarily for light Bohemian and Pilsner lagers
Used to add fermentables without increasing body or flavor. Produces a milder, less grainy tasting beer. Examples: American lagers, Bohemian lagers, Pilsners
Pilsner base malt
German base for Pilsners and Bohemian Lagers
Belgian base malt for Continental lagers
Very light lager malt used to make Pilsners, Lagers and other light beers. May be used as a base malt.
Kiln dried malt darker than Pale Malt, but not as dark as Munich Malt Imparts a golden to orange color to the beer.
Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.
Base malt for all beer styles
Base malt for all beer styles
Base malt for all English beer styles Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt
Base malt for all beer styles Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts
Also called "English Mild" - a light specialty malt used in Brown Ales
Acid malt contains acids from natural lactic acids. Used by German brewers to adjust malt PH without chemicals to adhere to German purity laws. Also enhances the head retention.
Provides a very strong malt flavor and aroma to your beer.
Use for English ales, nut brown ales and porters. Adds a toasted, biscuit like flavor and aroma
Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.
Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

Toasted malt can be made at home by toasting pale malted barley for 10-15 minutes at 350 F. Similar to Biscuit or Victory malt - this malt adds reddish/orange color and improved body without sweetness. Toasted flavor. Mashing required to avoid haze.
Aromatic malt from Banberg, Germany. Promotes a full flavor and rounds off beer color. Promotes deep red color and malty flavor.
Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey. Also called Brumalt.
Dark German malt developed to add malt flavor of Alt, Marzen and Oktoberfest beers. Helps create authentic maltiness without having to do a decoction mash. Rarely available for homebrewers.
Use for English ales, brown ales and porters. Adds a biscuit like flavor and aroma. Can be used as a substitute for toasted malt.
Roasted specialty malt used in some English browns, milds and old ales to add color and a biscuit taste. Intense flavor - so limit use. Low diastatic power so must be mashed with well modified malts.
Malted oats. Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Creates chill haze in lighter beers, so is primarily used in dark ones.

Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Used in oatmeal stouts and porters Adds substantial protein haze to light beers Protein rest recommended unless flakes are pregelatinized
Havervlokken

Raw, unmalted barley can be used to add body to your beer. Use in homebrew requires very fine milling combined with a decoction or multi-stage mash. Performs best when used in small quantities with well modified grains.
Adds significant body to Porters and Stouts. High haze producing protein prevents use in light beers.
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a orange to deep orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers
Unhopped Wheat liquid malt extract. Contains approx 60% Wheat, 40% Barley Use for Bavarian wheats, weizens, weiss and dunkel weizen styles.
Wheat based dry extract for use in all wheat beers. Use as base or to increase gravity of any wheat beer. Examples: Weizen, weiss, wheat ales and lagers
Light, raw brown sugar. May be used in British pale ales or high gravity Belgian ales. Limit percentage used to avoid undesirable flavors. Similar to Demerara sugar.

UK mixture of molasses, invert sugar and golden (corn) syrup. Imparts an intense sweet flavor and dark color. Used in dark English ales. Also called "Black Treacle" or the brand name "Lyle's Black Treacle Syrup."
White table sugar, or sucrose primarily is used to increase alcohol. Using too much will add a cider flavor to beer.
Extreme caramel aroma and flavored malt. Used in dark Belgian Abbey and Trappist ales. Unique flavor and aroma.
Malt that has been smoked over an open fire. Creates a distinctive "smoked" flavor and aroma. Used primarily for German Rauchbier but can also be added to Brown Ales and Porters.
Imparts a dry, crisp rye flavor to rye beers. Can be easier to mash than raw rye.
Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer. Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.

Roasted at high temperature to create a burnt, grainy, coffee like flavor. Imparts a red to deep brown color to beer, and very strong roasted flavor. Use 2-4% in Brown ales to add a nutty flavor, or 3-10% in Porters and Stouts for coffee flavor.

Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

Used like other rice adjuncts in American and Japenes lagers to provide a dry, clean taste and light body. Adds gravity without changing body or flavor substantially. Use in place of corn sugar in small quantities.
Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.
Robust smoky malt that provides a smoky flavor. Used in scottish ales and wee heavy ales.
Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.
Imparts a strong, sweet flavor. Used primarily in stouts and porters.
Not fermentable, so it adds lasting sweetness. Lactose can be added to lend sweetness to Sweet Stouts and Porters.
If added during the boil it will add a dry, woodsy flavor. If added at bottling, the smooth maple flavor comes through. Used for maple ales, porters, browns.
Liquid Invert Sugar. Used to increase alcohol and lighten the beer without alterning flavor. Used in Belgian ales and some English ales.
Pale dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any full bodied ale or lager.
Used to increase starting gravity and also as an adjunct for some Belgian and English ales.
Can be used to lighten flavor and body when substituted for malt. Generally limit to 30% when used as an adjunct. Pasturize and add to primary during fermentation. Use up to 100% for meads.
Imparts a corn or grain taste. Mash required. Used to increase gravity of American lagers.
Very light color dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any ale or lager.
Dark, unrefined brown sugar that contains molasses and other dark impurities. Great for brown ales and porters. Adds slight sweetness and smooth character.
Unhopped dark liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any dark beer. Examples: Porter, Brown ale, Bock, Oktoberfest, Stouts
Dark dry extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any dark ale or lager.
Syrup derived from corn with many of the same properties as corn sugar. May be used to enhance gravity without adding much body or flavor. Limit percentage in batch to avoid wine/cider flavors.
Widely used for bottling at rate of approx 2/3 cup per 5 gallons of beer
Intensifies aroma and color in top-fermented beers such as dark wheat beers.
Primarily used for color and aroma in top-fermented specialty beers.
Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

Light Belgian crystal malt. Used in light Trappist and Abbey style Belgian ales.

Caramel, copper colored malt. Used in Belgian ales and German bocks.

Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.
Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.

Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.
Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

Unmalted barley roasted at high temperature to create a dry, coffee like flavor. Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts. Gives "dryness" to a stout or porter -- much more so than regular Roasted Barley
Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.
Raw barley that has been "popped" open to open kernels Used in place of raw barley for faster conversion and higher yields. High in haze producing protein

Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.
Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock
Amber colored dry malt extract, for general purpose use. Use in any medium to dark colored beer. Examples: Ales, Marzens, Amber Ale, India Pale Ale

BEST Acidulated Malt reduces the pH of the mash. This results in improved enzyme activity of the mash, greater yield and flavor stability as well as a lighter color and a balanced aroma in the finished beer. It also represents an interesting alternative for breweries that have no mash acidification.

BEST Caramel Aromatic will impart a distinct, almost exaggerated malt aroma and flavor to red lagers, amber lagers, dark lagers, German bocks and other beer styles, even at a rate as los as 10 %. As with all BEST caramel malts, this malt is of exceptional quality, both due to its excellent processing characteristics and superior flavor.

BEST Black Malt eXtra (roasted malt) gives the beer extremely deep colors and intensive roasted bread, dark chocolate or coffee notes. The malt flavor is also emphasized. Similar to the somewhat ligther BEST Black Malt, the eXtra version is also produced from green or kiln-dried malt which is roasted using a smooth and gentle technology. While roasting can result in undesirable pyrazine tastes, our BESTMALZ roasting technology applies the heat in a statd of the art fashion. This malt is as black as great malt can be. It will enrich your brew with a wild spectrum of tastes.

BEST Black Malt (roasted malt) gives the beer greater depth of color and adds more intensive nuances of chocolate or coffee aromas. The malt flavour is also emphasised. The foam characteristics are not affected. The malt is produced from green or kiln-dried malt which is roasted using a smooth and gentle technology. While roasting can result in undesirable pyrazine tastes. Our BESTMALZ roasting technology applies the heat in a state-of-the-art fashion. Evenly roasted malt kernels with optimal processing features are the outcomes of this advanced technique fine tuned by our experienced malt masters.

BEST Caramel Amber reinforces the typical `caramely´ malt aroma of the beer. It gives the beer a darker color and increases foam stability. In addition, it enhances the full-bodied character of the beer. After the germination is finished, the green malt is gently roasted using a special process. This produces the unique BESTMALZ caramel aroma.

BEST Caramel Hell reinforces the typical “caramely” malt aroma of the beer. It gives the beer a darker color and increases foam stability. In addition, it enhances the full-bodied creamy character of the beer. After the germination is finished, the green malt is gently roasted using a special process. This creates the special caramel aroma. This malt is produced by our specifially developed germination and roasting technique. The malt has a unique with an elegant touch of sweatness. It has excellent processing characteristics. This malt has rich and superior flavors.

BEST Caramel Pils optimizes the foam properties and sweet full-bodied character of the beer. The malt character resembles that of BEST Pilsner malt. After the germination is finished, the green malt is gently roasted and optimized over many years by our BESTMALZ malt masters. This process is responsible for our unique BESTMALZ Caramel aromas. As all our BEST caramel malts, this malt impresses with excellent processing characteristics and with a superior flavor.

BEST Melanoidin contains a particularly large amount of dextrins. It gives the beer a strong flavor and a reddish color. The full-bodied nature of the beer is enhanced. It is produced according to a speial kilning process. Without any problems can it be used in percentages of up to 50 % despite its strongly coloring impact.

BEST Munich intensifies the color of the beer. It emphasises the malt aroma of dark beer in an exciting way. It forms an excellent enzyme-rich foundation for all color-intensive beer styles. This malt is produced using a special malting process designed to bring out certain desirable qualities, such as high solubility.

BEST Munich Dark gives a pleasant full-bodied and malty flavor. The impact when using this darker malt is similar to BEST Munich: the color is even more intensified, the malt aroma ist strengthened. Enzyme richness of this malt offers opportunities for brewing strongly colored beers. The production process for this malt is similar to the lighter variant of our BEST Munich.

BEST Pale Ale deepens the light “golden” color of top-fermented beers, creating a pleasant flavor. It forms an excellent enzyme-rich foundation for intensive colored beer styles. It is an excellent base malt for brewing many different styles of British Pale Ale as well as for brewing Kölsch beer.

BEST Pilsen Malt gives beer a fresh and rounded taste. It is used for all types of beers based on basically berley malt. It forms an excellent “light” and enzyme-rich foundation for almost all beer styles. Malt characteristics: low protein levels, high extract content, light color and high enzymatic activity. BEST Pilsen Malt is also available in organic quality.

BEST Red X has been invented for brewing red-tinted beers. You can use BEST Red X for up to 100% of your grain bill – no other malt is required. Offering exceptional reliability and optimal processability, BEST Red X can be employed to brew consistently fiery beers with intense reddish hues. Its full-bodied flavor and attractive, unique color coupled with easy handling in the brewery make BEST Red X the best choice for creating a broad range of new beers, such as red-tinted wheat beers.

BEST Smoked gives beer a typical smoky flavor similar to that in smoked ham. The quantity used will influence the intensity of the beech wood or whisky flavor. This malt can not only be used for beer but also for distillate production. It has high enzymatic activity.

BEST Vienna deepens the light and brilliant color of the beer and creates a pleasant, full-bodied and malty taste. Selected malting barley is used to produce the malt and it is created according to a special malting process. This malt has a high enzymatic potential.

BEST Wheat Malt emphasises the effervescent freshness and the typical top-fermented flavor of wheat beer. It is produced from high quality brewing wheat. Malting processes adapted to the raw material highlight the particular qualities of this malt.

BEST Wheat Malt Dark emphasises the effervescent freshness and the typical top-fermented flavor of wheat beer. Very much like our brighter version of BEST Wheat Malt does. This malt, however, adds color and intensifies the aroma. It is produced from high quality brewing wheat. Malting processes adapted to the raw material highlight the particular qualities of this malt.

BEST Special X imparts to beer- depending on the amount in the grist - a smooth raosty flavor reminiscent of raisins or dried fruit. The beer posesses a chestnut to dark hue (depending on rate) and an aromatic and harmonious full- bodied character. The malt does not, however, introduce bitter roasted flavors but rather brings a mild smoothness to beer without any of the astingent qualities associated with other dark malts. BEST Special X is a cool and crafty malt - product. Any craft - brewer should try- out this malt in his or her creations and impress with a rich mix of flavors.

BEST Caramel Munich I brings out the full spectrum of caramel taste that nature has put in the kernel. Like our other caramels, this malt will darken your beer and stabilize its foam. Depending on grain bill composition nuts and almonds may be reflected. Like all our BESTMALZ caramels, BEST Caramel Munich I to III are produced by using a unique germination and roasting technuque. Our malt masters have developed this gentle but yet effective process in order to generate caramel tastes of different variations and degrees. As a result, all BEST Caramels have great processing features and are highly comfortable in their use.

BEST Heidelberg is used especially for brewing beers extremely light in color. It forms an excellent `light´ and enzymerich foundation for almost all beer styles. Malt characteristics: low protein levels, high extract content, very light color and high enzymatic activity.

BEST Melanoidin Light contains an appreciable amont of dextrines and Maillard products, which emphasize the rich taste and flavor stability of the beer. It gives the beer a fuller flavor and a sligtly reddish color. The fullbodied nature of the beer is enhanced. It is produced according to a special kilning process.

BEST Chocolate gives the beer an even darker color- like dark chocolate. It adds fine nuances of chocolate, nut, or coffee aromas. Dosages up to 10 % are possible without any bitter pryazine flavor. The color of the foam will not be affected but foam stability will be improved. The malt is produced from green or kiln-dried malt in a gentle roasting process.

BEST Heidelberg Wheat Malt emphasizes the effervescent freshness and the typical top-fermented flavor of wheat beer. If can be used for light-colored beers. It is produced from high quality brewing wheat. Malting processes adapted to the raw material highlight the particular qualities of this malt.

BEST Caramel Munich II ist our mid range Munich caramel: very `caramely´ , adding deep color, increasing foam stability. In addition, it enhances the fullbodied character of the beer with intensive nut flavors. BEST Caramel Munich I to III are produced by using a unique germination and roasting technique. Our malt maters have developed this gentle but yet effective process in order to generate caramel tastes of different variations and degrees. All our BEST Caramels have unique processing feartures and are highly comfortable in their use.

BEST Chit Malt is used for balancing the characteristics of strongly solubilized malt. When using this malt, foam formation is promoted and foam stability increases. The malt is produced from the same two-row spring barley as is used for all other BESTMALZ malt types.

BEST Peated is smoked over a peat fire using the best avaiable peat. The smoke imparts a strong smoky, phenolic flavor which is reflected in the malt aroma. Brewers can use up to 100 % in the grain bill. Depending on the composition and intensity in the grain bill this malt will generate flavors from light to intense peat and earthy tastes. Great not only for beers but also for distullates. (Phenols 5-50 ppm)

BEST Caramel Munich III (crystal malt) intensifies the beer color and malty aroma of dark caramels and dried fruits. It gives the beer a significantly darker color and increases foam stability. In addition, it enhances the full-bodied character of the beer with flavor of intensive roasted almond. BEST Caramel Munich I to III are produced by using a unique germination and roasting technique. Our malt maters have developed this gentle but yet effective process in order to generate caramel tastes of different variations and degrees. Brew master love this dark malt for its unique features.

BEST Roasted Barley imparts a characteristic deep dark color to beer. Depending on the amount used in the grain bill, the flavor profile can exhibit intense roasty notes and bitterness reminiscent of black coffee or Italian espresso. The foam stability of the beer is also improved.

BEST Spelt Malt is used for producing full-bodied, top-fermented beers. Spelt is an ancient grain and is know to possess a number of healt beneifits. For this reason, spelt was the favorite grain of the medieval pioneers of today´s health movement. German nun, Hildegrad von Bingen, born in the year 1098 is famous for using spelt in her recipes. Likewise, spelt beer, is considerd highly digestible and conductive to good health. This malt improves foam stability. It can also have other positive effects in the brewing process.

BEST Rye Malt imparts an incomparable structure, a velvetly smooth mouthfeel and an extraordinary complexity. The aroma intensely reminds of bread crumbs. Due to missing husks and the high amount of mucilage (pentosanes) more than 60 % of BEST Rye Malt in the grain bill is not recommended, as it leads to serious lauteing problems.
Roasted specialty malt used in some English browns, milds and old ales to add color and a biscuit taste. Intense flavor - so limit use. Low diastatic power so must be mashed with well modified malts.
Malted black barley adds a strong burnt coffee flavor - suitable for stouts and porters.
Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.
Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.
Pronounced Caramel, Slight Burnt Sugar, Raisniny, Prune Red to Deep Red 3-15% in Amber and Red beers. 10-15% in Bock beers. 7-15% in Dark beers. 10-15% in Porter and Stout.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Very Dark
Adds body, color and improves head retention.
Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.
Base malt for all English beer styles
Deep roasted barley - adds the dry bitter flavor characteristic of Irish and Imperial Stouts.
Flaked barley - may be used in single step mash to increase body of beer. Typically used in stouts and porters for body and head retention.
Malted black barley adds a strong burnt coffee flavor - suitable for stouts and porters.
Made from green malt - imparts a light malt flavor and slight hue. Suitable for light ales, lagers.
Dark chocolate malt from the UK. Adds strong coffee flavor to your beer.
Caramel or crystal malt from Thomas Fawcett. Adds Toffee caramel flavor. Improves head retention and body.
Crystalized Rye malt - adds a dry liquorice toffee flavor and quite a bit of color to your beer.
Crystalized wheat malt - adds a dry biscuity flavor, and quite a bit of color.
Unmalted corn flaked for use in a single step infusion mash. Used primarily to add fermentables without substantially changing body. Use in light bodied ales and lagers.
Malted oats - used in stouts and porters to add body and head retention as well as a unique flavor.
Floor malted spring barley from the UK. Suitable base male for all types of ales.
Floor malted winter barley from the UK, suitable for both lagers and ales.
Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.
Deep roasted barley - adds the dry bitter flavor characteristic of Irish Stouts.
Unmalted wheat torrified for use in a single step infusion. Typically used for Wits and other wheats where raw unmalted wheat is called for.

Has a light, biscuity dry flavor and can be used to product Bitter and Mild Ales and sweet Stouts as well as the traditional London Porters that have come back into favor recently.
Flavor Contributions: Light, Biscuity Dry Flavor
British malts are more modified than American, lending a fuller body.
Made from a blend of pale and crystal malts, this balanced malt extract is ideal for Bitter and Ale style beers.

A roasted malt colored to a higher degree than Chocolate Malt in the roasting process. Black Malt has no diastatic activity and no fermentable extract and is simply used to add flavor and color in dark beers such as milds, porters and stouts. Flavor Contributions: Coffee, Intense Bitter, Dry

This is a light crystal malt used to add body and sweetness to beer without adding too much color.
Flavor Contributions: Adds body and sweetness
British malts are more modified than American, lending a fuller body.

Bursting with flavors of caramel, toffee and biscuit, Munton's crystal 60 has a medium amber-brown color contribution when used as a part of the grist. It will increase residual sweetness as well as improving foam stability, increasing body and adding wonderful aromatics to beer. It can be used whenever crystal malt is called for, and while it creates wonderful British style beers, it also works extremely well in just about any beer style. It is commonly used in pale ales, IPAs, bitter, milds, stouts, porters, and other styles as well.

A roasted malt colored to a higher degree than Chocolate Malt in the roasting process. Black Malt has no diastatic activity and no fermentable extract and is simply used to add flavor and color in dark beers such as milds, porters and stouts.
Flavor Contributions: Coffee, Intense Bitter, Dry
British malts are more modified than American, lending a fuller body.
Made from a blend of pale and crystal malts, this balanced malt extract is ideal for Bitter and Ale style beers.
Made from the lightest available lager malt, processed carefully with the gentlest heat necessary to ensure that the resultant extract is the lightest possible from 100% malt.

Lager Malt is kilned at a low temperature to ensure that the malt is a pale color with a delicate flavour but also to preserve a high level of diastatic activity. Modern lager malts are now fully modified and therefore a simple infusion mash can be used. The diastatic activity of lager malt means that a good proportion of unmalted grains may safely be included in the mash if required.
Made from the lightest available lager malt, processed carefully with the gentlest heat necessary to ensure that the resultant extract is the lightest possible from 100% malt.
Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

Muntons Maris Otter malt is a 2-row winter variety of barley specially bred for use in the brewing industry. It has a low nitrogen content and high quality malt characteristics which give beers a lush, full flavor profile. It is generally regarded as having a more rich maltiness than standard American 2-row varieties that have been bred specifically for yield. Plump kernels with good husks for filtration, Maris Otter has a breadiness that goes well in British style ales, but may be used in any recipe where more malt character and a more rounded flavor are desired.

Muntons English pale malt is a fully modified base malt that can be used in a number of beers. It works best as a base in British and American style ales, but can be used as part or all of the base for other beers as well, since it is easy to work with and has a great flavor. Pale malt is generally more highly kilned than standard 2-row malt, and as a result it is slightly bready and has a richer flavor profile than 2-row.
This is a good base to use in a number of beer styles, from lighter pale ales and bitters to darker porters and stouts. Give this a try next time you are putting together a beer that requires a clean yet slightly rich flavor profile.

Roasted barley is the quintessential grain used in the production of classic dry Irish stouts. Made from unmalted barley that has been deeply roasted, Munton's roasted barley adds a deep roasted flavor and aroma to beers. In addition, it can add a drying quality and roasty bitterness to beers in which it is included as part of the grist. Most notably used in stouts, it can also be used in small proportions in other dark beers such as porters, stouts, milds, dunkelweizens, and browns.

Red wheat malt. Wheat malt gives beer a sweet, creamy, malty flavor. Used at high percentages of 40 to 75 percent in wheat beers for distinct wheat character. In smaller proportions of 2 to 10 percent it adds smoothness and foam stability.
Useful for almost any English-style ale for head retention & complexity.

For all traditional wheat beer styles, the Dried Wheat Malt Extract provides body and richness and is essential for brewing German Style Wheat Beers and a small amount aids in head retention for a variety of beer styles. Formulation of Wheat Dried Malt Extract emulates the recipe ratio of many classic German wheat beers.

Grain.F_G_CONVERT_GRAIN: Briess Base Malts, Caramel 60L Malt, Munich Malt
